Federal Court
Harrington, J.
October 30, 2003.
Counsel:
Michael J. Mussieux, for the applicant;
Rick Garvin, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Kevin E. Moore Law Office, Edmonton, Alberta, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. This case was originally cited as [2003] F.T.R. TBEd. NO.028.

[1]
Harrington, J.
: The applicant seeks a stay of the removal order issued against him in October 2000. Its execution was delayed as the applicant was then in prison. He was paroled in April 2003. On September 12, 2003 the Minister's Delegate dismissed the applicant's Pre-Removal Risk Assessment ("PRRA"). An application for leave and for judicial review of that decision is currently pending.

[2]
Despite the very able arguments put forth on the applicant's behalf, I am not satisfied that a stay of the removal order would be justified in the present case.

[3]
The applicant, Leacroft Antonio Lewis, is 27 years of age. He immigrated to Canada in 1990 when he was 13, sponsored by his mother. His mother, step-father and several siblings are Canadian citizens, and he is currently a permanent resident of Canada.

[4]
The applicant's difficulty is that he was convicted in 1998 of six charges of robbery and attempted robbery for which he was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment. In February 2000 the Minister's Delegate issued an opinion pursuant to section 70(5) of the former Immigration Act, (R.S.C. 1985, c.I-2, as amended) that the applicant constituted a danger to the public in Canada and deportation was ordered that October. In January 2001, the Immigration Appeal Division dismissed his appeal of that order, and in July 2001, the Federal Court Trial Division dismissed his application for leave and judicial review thereof.

[5]
There is a wealth of jurisprudence dealing with the stay of execution of removal orders. Reference is usually made to the tripartite test for interim injunctions as applied in the immigration context in  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.). The applicant must show that (1) there is a serious issue in the underlining application, (in this case the application for leave and for judicial review of the negative pre-removal risk assessment); (2) that he would suffer irreparable harm if the stay was not granted; and (3) that the balance of convenience is in his favour.

[6]
With respect to the serious issue the Minister's Delegate said, amongst other things, that:
Mr. Lewis failed to indicate ... whether or not he actually had access to [his] children. Mr. Lewis also has not provided any specifics with respect to future contacts with the children. It is my opinion that Mr. Lewis has failed to demonstrate that there are any humanitarian factors present in his case which would warrant favourable consideration.

[7]
It was argued quite strenuously that these conclusions flew in the face of the uncontradicted evidence of the applicant, his common-law partner, Mary Valdez, and Ms. Valdez' friend, Bonnie Pinder.

[8]
Even if I were to hold that the applicant met the threshold necessary on this point, I am not satisfied that the Minister's Delegate was wrong in concluding that no irreparable harm would come to the applicant in that he is not in need of protection. Much of his subjective fear is grounded in a drug deal gone bad. He admits to stealing drugs from a Jamaican posse in Edmonton, and actually went into hiding for some months thereafter. His concerns are highly speculative. There is no evidence that his removal to Jamaica will cause him irreparable harm.

[9]
It is quite true that the removal may cause some difficulty in his relationship with his children, particularly his son with Ms. Valdez, and may put a strain on their conjugal relationship. It will also be stressful for the applicant to return to the land of his birth considering that he has spent more than half his life in Canada. However, these issues are inherent to and arise naturally from a removal order. The irreparable harm must be more than a normal consequence ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (Pinard J.) and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , (MacKay J.)).

[10]
The application for leave and for judicial review of the negative PRRA is not before me. That application continues whether or not the applicant is in Canada. If it is set aside in a judicial review the applicant is entitled to return to Canada at the expense of the Minister, (s. 52(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c.27 ("IRPA")).

[11]
Furthermore, in his affidavit in support of the stay application, the applicant states that he is in the process of beginning a Humanitarian and Compassionate application, as well as a sponsorship application through his fiancée. An application based on humanitarian and compassionate considerations, pursuant to s. 25 of the IRPA, is distinct from an application for leave and for judicial review of a PRRA and can be pursued while he is in Jamaica.

[12]
For these reasons, the application is dismissed.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration Act, (R.S.C. 1985, c.I-2, as amended) section 70(5)
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c.27 ("IRPA") s. 52(2)
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c.27 ("IRPA") s. 25
legal_issues: The requirements for granting a stay of execution of a removal order.
The standard for demonstrating a 'serious issue' in an underlying application relevant to a stay of removal.
The threshold for establishing 'irreparable harm' necessary to justify a stay of removal, particularly concerning humanitarian factors and risk of harm in the country of origin.
Whether disruption to family relationships constitutes irreparable harm sufficient to warrant a stay of removal.
The interplay between a pending application for judicial review and the availability of a stay of removal.
The ability to pursue alternative immigration applications (humanitarian and compassionate grounds, sponsorship) from outside of the country.
The application of a tripartite test (serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience) in the context of immigration law and stays of removal.
factual_background: An individual, Leacroft Antonio Lewis, applied for a stay of a removal order issued in October 2000.
The execution of the removal order was initially delayed due to the applicant's imprisonment.
The applicant was paroled in April 2003.
On September 12, 2003, a Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) for the applicant was dismissed by the Minister's Delegate.
The applicant subsequently applied for leave and judicial review of the PRRA decision, which application was pending at the time of this case.
The applicant immigrated to Canada from Jamaica in 1990 at the age of 13, sponsored by his mother.
The applicant's mother, step-father, and siblings are Canadian citizens, and he is a permanent resident of Canada.
In 1998, the applicant was convicted of six charges of robbery and attempted robbery and sentenced to seven years' imprisonment.
In February 2000, the Minister's Delegate determined the applicant constituted a danger to the public, leading to a deportation order in October 2000.

The applicant's appeal of the deportation order was dismissed by the Immigration Appeal Division in January 2001, and a subsequent application for leave and judicial review was dismissed by the Federal Court Trial Division in July 2001.
The Minister's Delegate noted the applicant did not provide sufficient information regarding access to or future contact with his children.
The applicant has a common-law partner, Mary Valdez, and a child with her.
The applicant stated he was pursuing a Humanitarian and Compassionate application and a sponsorship application through his fiancée.

Applicants: The Minister's Delegate's conclusions regarding humanitarian factors were unsupported by the uncontradicted evidence of the applicant, his common-law partner, and her friend.
Removal would cause difficulty in the applicant’s relationship with his children and strain his conjugal relationship with Ms. Valdez.
Removal would be stressful for the applicant, having spent more than half his life in Canada.
The applicant is pursuing a Humanitarian and Compassionate application and a sponsorship application through his fiancée.
There is a serious issue in the underlying application for leave and judicial review of the negative Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA).
The applicant would suffer irreparable harm if the stay was not granted.
Respondents: The applicant failed to demonstrate any humanitarian factors warranting favourable consideration, specifically regarding access to and future contact with his children.
The applicant’s fear of harm is speculative and grounded in a past drug deal, with no evidence of actual risk upon removal to Jamaica.
Any difficulties arising from removal (relationship with children, stress of returning to Jamaica) are inherent consequences of a removal order and do not constitute irreparable harm.
The application for leave and judicial review of the PRRA can proceed regardless of the applicant’s location.

court_analysis: The court applied the tripartite test for interim injunctions (derived from immigration jurisprudence) to the applicant's request for a stay of the removal order, requiring demonstration of a serious issue in the underlying application, irreparable harm, and a balance of convenience in the applicant's favour.

The court found the applicant did not establish irreparable harm. While acknowledging the difficulties a removal order would cause to the applicant’s relationships and his personal adjustment, the court determined these were inherent consequences of deportation and did not rise to the level of 'irreparable harm' required for a stay, citing precedent that such harm must be more than a normal consequence of removal.
The court discounted the applicant’s fears of harm in Jamaica as speculative, grounding them in a past drug-related incident and finding no evidence to support a claim of actual risk upon return.

The court reasoned that the applicant’s pending application for leave and judicial review of the negative PRRA remained viable regardless of his location, and a successful review would entitle him to return to Canada at the government’s expense (citing s. 52(2) of IRPA).

The court noted the applicant’s intention to pursue humanitarian and compassionate grounds (s. 25 IRPA) and sponsorship applications, clarifying these could proceed even if the applicant were removed to Jamaica, and were distinct from the PRRA judicial review.
The court ultimately dismissed the application for a stay, concluding the applicant had not met the necessary threshold for demonstrating justification under the established legal test.
final_outcome: The application for a stay of the removal order was dismissed.
